properties.name: 1. At Palais de justice
properties.description: Posted by AsmaaThe Project 55 audio tour, which recounts the history of the Main, begins here at the bus stop across from the Palais de justice. You can download the mp3 at their website.

properties.name: 1205 Rue St-Denis
properties.description: Posted by Asmaa Montreal

properties.name: 1205 St. Denis
properties.description: Posted by Asmaa MontrealPavilion N, at 1205 St. Denis St., houses the faculties of philosophy, sexology, legal sciences, religion and social work.

properties.name: 2. At Notre Dame Basilica
properties.description: Posted by AsmaaNathalie, driver of STM bus 55, nears the end of her route as she passes the Notre Dame Basilica. She will now turn east to St. Laurent and return north along the Main. (Allen McInnis/The Gazette)

properties.name: 3. Going through Chinatown
properties.description: Posted by AsmaaAccording to Project 55, Montreal\'s ethnic neighbourhoods, like Chinatown, have been, and continue to be, in constant movement. (Allen McInnis/The Gazette)

properties.name: 4. The de Bullion detour
properties.description: Posted by AsmaaPeople go about their business while Bus 55 rides up its detour route past Prince Arthur. (Allen McInnnis/The Gazette)

properties.name: 455 Rene Levesque E
properties.description: Posted by Asmaa MontrealPavilion W, located at 455 Rene Levesque E and linked through a walkway to Pavilion N, houses the faculty of education and specialized learning.

properties.name: 5. Approaching Laurier
properties.description: Posted by AsmaaThe bus holds back as a cyclist rides in the middle of the traffic lane on St. Laurent approaching Laurier. (Allen McInnis/The Gazette)

properties.name: 6. Under Van Horne overpass
properties.description: Posted by AsmaaThe bus rides along its route up St. Laurent under the Van Horne railway tracks. (Allen McInnis/The Gazette)

properties.name: 7. Through Little Italy
properties.description: Posted by AsmaaLittle Italy\'s sidewalk cafes are already starting to fill up. (Allen McInnis/The Gazette)

properties.name: 8. Past Jean-Talon
properties.description: Posted by AsmaaThe students behind Project 55 imagine the Main, here just north of Jean-Talon, as a type of cosmic glue that holds the city together. (Allen McInnis/The Gazette)

properties.name: 9. End of the line at Chabanel
properties.description: Posted by AsmaaBus 55 sits at the end of the line, on Chabanel St., before beginning its return voyage south along St. Laurent Blvd. and then St. Urbain St. (Allen McInnis/The Gazette)

properties.name: Burger King
properties.description: Posted by Asmaa6150, boul. Henri-Bourassa Est Two Lester B. Pearson students having lunch say a group of students from Henri Bourassa started throwing ice cubes at them. Pearson student screams racist comment at them.

properties.name: Burger King
properties.description: Posted by AsmaaTwo Lester B. Pearson students having lunch say a group of students from Henri Bourassa started throwing ice cubes at them. Pearson student screams racist comment at them.

properties.name: Carignan Park
properties.description: Posted by Asmaa Two students attacked as they walked back to the park on their way back two school. Left with bumps, scratches and bruises.

properties.name: Carignan Park
properties.description: Posted by Asmaa Two students attacked as they walked back to the park on their way back two school. Left with bumps, scratches and bruises.

properties.name: Chez Bong
properties.description: Posted by Asmaa1012 St. Laurent Blvd., near Viger St., 514-396-7779. Open Tues. to Sun. 11 a.m. to 9 p.m.; closed Mon. Licensed. MC, Visa. Like a Korean Chalet BBQ, Chez Bong’s wood-panelled room draws diners with sizzling platters of meats, including beef ribs in saty-sweet marinade. Greasy deep-fried dumplings, pork, kimchi and tofu stir-fry, and spicy soups are a little heavy but very homemade. (Sarah Musgrave, May 2007) Korean Good bet $ $

properties.name: Chez Bong
properties.description: Posted by Asmaa1012 St. Laurent Blvd. montreal1012 St. Laurent Blvd., near Viger St., 514-396-7779. Open Tues. to Sun. 11 a.m. to 9 p.m.; closed Mon. Licensed. MC, Visa. Greasy deep-fried dumplings, pork, kimchi and tofu stir-fry, and spicy soups are a little heavy but very homemade. (Sarah Musgrave, May 2007) Korean Good bet $ $

properties.name: Ecole secondaire Henri-Bourassa
properties.description: Posted by AsmaaAn influx of police community-relations officers are expected to sit down with students and teachers at the French-language school - "as many as possible" - at both schools "beginning this week," in an attempt to lessen community tensions, said Montreal police Constable Laurent Gingras.

properties.name: Ecole secondaire Henro-Bourassa
properties.description: Posted by Asmaa6051, boul. Maurice-Duplessis, Montréal-NordAn influx of police community-relations officers are expected to sit down with students and teachers at the French-language school - "as many as possible" - at both schools "beginning this week," in an attempt to lessen community tensions, said Montreal police Constable Laurent Gingras.

properties.name: Hanashima
properties.description: Posted by Asmaade 75 la Gauchetière St. W. montreal75 la Gauchetière St. W. 514-396-4746. Lunch and dinner daily. Licensed. Visa, Mastercard and Interac. From the realm of DIY dining comes Japanese shabu shabu, an unusual hot-potting experience in which customers custom-cook their meals at individual cooking stations. There are three bubbling broths (chicken, traditional and spicy) for simmering spinach-like greens, cabbage, enoki mushrooms, daikon, watercress and other veggies, along with your choice of finely sliced meats or seafood. Good clean fun, down to the sesame or green tea ice cream for dessert. (Sarah Musgrave, March 2007) Japanese Good bet $ $

properties.name: Hanashima
properties.description: Posted by Asmaa 75 la Gauchetière St. W. 514-396-4746. Lunch and dinner daily. Licensed. Visa, Mastercard and Interac. properties.name: Kremlin
properties.description: Posted by Asmaa1015 Beaver Hall Hill, 514-876-0555. Mon.-Sat. 10 a.m. to 8 p.m. or later. Licensed. Cavernous Kremlin is dedicated to the esthetics and the eats of the former USSR. Under hammer and sickle insignia, waitresses in Soviet youth camp outfits deliver decently prepared rib-sticking meats and starches, from varenecki dumplings to beef blinchike rolls to chicken schnitzel, along with a surprisingly succulent eggplant appetizer. (Sarah Musgrave, Aug. 2006) Soviet Fair bet $ $

properties.name: Kremlin
properties.description: Posted by Asmaa1015 Beaver Hall montreal1015 Beaver Hall Hill, 514-876-0555. Mon.-Sat. 10 a.m. to 8 p.m. or later. Licensed. properties.name: La Iguana
properties.description: Posted by Asmaa51 Roy St. E. 514-844-0893. Dinner Sun.-Wed. 5 p.m.-11 p.m.; Thurs. 5 p.m.-midnight; Fri. 5 p.m.-midnight., Sat. 5 p.m.-midnight. Licensed. Visa, MC, Interac. Not an address for authentic comida mexicana but for kitschy cocktails and copious cheesy offerings. Stuffed jalapeños and chicken enchiladas in brandy sauce fare better than traditional recipes like cochinita pibil. (Sarah Musgrave, Aug. 2004) Tex-Mex Fair bet $ $

properties.name: La Iguana
properties.description: Posted by Asmaa51 Roy St. E. montreal51 Roy St. E. 514-844-0893. Dinner Sun.-Wed. 5 p.m.-11 p.m.; Thurs. 5 p.m.-midnight; Fri. 5 p.m.-midnight., Sat. 5 p.m.-midnight. Licensed. Visa, MC, Interac. Not an address for authentic comida mexicana but for kitschy cocktails and copious cheesy offerings. Stuffed jalapeños and chicken enchiladas in brandy sauce fare better than traditional recipes like cochinita pibil. (Sarah Musgrave, Aug. 2004) Tex-Mex Fair bet $ $

properties.name: La Paryse
properties.description: Posted by Asmaa302 Ontario St. E. (514) 842-2040 Open Tues. to Fri. 11 a.m. to 11 p.m.; Sat. noon to 10:30 p.m.; Sun. noon to 10 p.m.; closed Mon. Licensed. All major cards. It would be clichéd to say long-standing La Paryse has “the best burgers in town,” but the all-beef patties at this cutesy diner are certainly a few grinds above the average. Vegetarians aren\'t the underclass here, however, with three burger options. Devouring sessions take place in two homey rooms in the Latin Quarter that often attract lineups in the entryway to beefdom. Accompanying your meal with a milkshake is optional, but you really oughta. (Sarah Musgrave, Mar 2006) Burgers $ Good bet

properties.name: La Paryse
properties.description: Posted by Asmaa302 Ontario St. montreal qc302 Ontario St. E. (514) 842-2040 Open Tues. to Fri. 11 a.m. to 11 p.m.; Sat. noon to 10:30 p.m.; Sun. noon to 10 p.m.; closed Mon. properties.name: Laloux
properties.description: Posted by Asmaa 250 Pine Ave. E. 514-287-9127. Lunch Mon.- Fri.; dinner daily. Major cards. Wheelchair access. For close to two decades, this “bistro de luxe” has been a gourmet oasis for diners eager for fine food, even finer wines and a gorgeous Gallic setting. Now with the arrival of the talented team of chef Danny St-Pierre and pastry chef Patrice Demers, this chic resto is flying high again, with the focus now on re-worked bistro classics such as coq au vin, braised lamb shoulder, hot foie gras, and pot de crème – all at more than reasonable prices. (Lesley Chesterman, May 2007) French HHH $ $ - $ $ $

properties.name: Le Caveau
properties.description: Posted by Asmaa2063 Victoria St. (514) 844-1624. Lunch weekdays; dinner daily. Major cards. A Montreal institution since 1949, this charming, three-story restaurant is a great choice for a night of civilized fine dining. The unpretentious French “cuisine bourgeoise” features hearty soups and bisques, delightful salads, and delicious French classics like duck confit, bavette/frites and choucroute. On top of that there’s a small but fine selection of French wines and service is exemplary. (Lesley Chesterman, Jan. 2007) French HHH $ $ - $ $ $ $

properties.name: Le Caveau
properties.description: Posted by Asmaa2063 Victoria St. (514) 844-1624. Lunch weekdays; dinner daily. Major cards. properties.name: Le Grand Comptoir
properties.description: Posted by Asmaa1225 Phillips Square montrealLe Grand Comptoir, 1225 Phillips Square (514) 393-3295 Open Mon. to Fri. 11:30 a.m. to 9 p.m. or later; Sat. noon to 10 p.m.; closed Sun. Licensed. All major cards. A longtime fixture on Phillips Square, Le Grand Comptoir\'s goal in life is to stay true to the standards of French cuisine. Cheap and classique if not particularly chic, it does most of its business at lunch, catering to workers and shoppers in the city core who have meat with sauce in mind, be that sirloin steak with Roquefort, or pork tenderloin in cream and mustard. (Sarah Musgrave, Dec 2006) French 8298 Good bet

properties.name: Le Grand Comptoir
properties.description: Posted by Asmaa1225 Phillips Square (514) 393-3295 Open Mon. to Fri. 11:30 a.m. to 9 p.m. or later; Sat. noon to 10 p.m.; closed Sun. Licensed. All major cards. properties.name: Le Latini
properties.description: Posted by Asmaa1130 Jeanne Mance St montreal

properties.name: Le Latini
properties.description: Posted by Asmaa1130 Jeanne Mance St. 514-861-3166. Lunch Mon.- Fri.; dinner daily. Major cards. If it\'s impeccably prepared, high-quality Italian food that you\'re looking for, Le Latini is the place, with affluent business types and regulars making up the majority of the crowd . Majestic, modern decor. Terrific risotto, veal and seafood, and the pasta is outstanding. Though pricey, the wine list is impressive. Yet considering the high prices, service sometimes comes up short. (Lesley Chesterman, Dec 2004)

properties.name: Le Nil Bleu
properties.description: Posted by Asmaa3706 St. Denis St.

properties.name: Le Nil Bleu
properties.description: Posted by Asmaa3706 St. Denis St. 514-285-4628. Open Mon. 6 to 11:30 p.m., Tues. to Sun. 11 a.m. to 11:30 p.m. Licensed. All major cards. The Ethiopian dining experience is out of the ordinary, even if Le Nil Bleu is not altogether out of this world. Rolls of injera, spongy like pancakes and dimpled like crumpets, are put to use to scoop up a variety of stewed concoctions like buttery doro alicha chicken and pleasantly arid berbère beef. (Sarah Musgrave, June 2007) Ethiopian Fair bet $ $

properties.name: Le Piemontais
properties.description: Posted by Asmaa1145 de Bullion Ave. montreal1145 de Bullion Ave. 514-861-8122. Lunch weekdays; dinner Mon.-Sat. Major cards. A well-loved Italian restaurant popular with celebrating families and the Radio-Canada crowd. Cuisine is solid Italian/Canadian fare. Outstanding service. Excellent and affordable wine list. As Place des Arts is just a few blocks north, it’s a good pick for pre- or post-concert supper. (Lesley Chesterman, Feb. 2007) Italian HH 1ž2 $ $ $

properties.name: Lester B. Pearson High School
properties.description: Posted by Asmaa 11575 AVENUE P.-M.-FAVIER, MONTRÉAL-NORD,Students, staff and parents of the two schools - English-language Lester B. Pearson High School and nearby French-language Ecole secondaire Henri Bourassa - are being promised visibly increased police presence around both buildings, Montreal police Constable Laurent Gingras said. He wouldn\'t provide details.

properties.name: Lester B. Pearson High School
properties.description: Posted by Asmaa 11575 AVENUE P.-M.-FAVIER, MONTRÉAL-NORD,Students, staff and parents of the two schools - English-language Lester B. He wouldn\'t provide details.

properties.name: MAP
properties.description: Posted by Asmaa2 sherbrooke st. e. montreal 2 Sherbrooke St. E., 514-843-8881. Open Mon. to Fri. 11:30 a.m. to 2 p.m.; Tues. to Sat. 6 p.m. to 11 p.m.; Sun. closed. Licensed. All major cards. A converted casse-croûte redone in beige and gold is a sunny spot for Basque-style tapas, small plates inspired by land and sea. Though it\'s run by nearby resto Pinxtos, the northern Spanish fare is somehow less convincing and less compelling here. Calamari, quail and scallop dishes conveyed adventurousness, main courses came across as simply average, and dessert of caramel-laced profiteroles captured the attention. (Sarah Musgrave, April 2007) Basque $ Fair to Good Bet

properties.name: Osaka
properties.description: Posted by Asmaa2137 Bleury St. montreal2137 Bleury St., 514-849-3438. Lunch Tues.-Fri. 11:45 a.m. to 2 p.m.; supper Tues. to Thurs. 6 p.m. to 9:30 p.m.; Fri. 6 p.m. to 10:15 p.m.; Sat. 5:30 p.m. to 10:15 p.m.; Sun. to 9 p.m.; closed Mon. Licensed. MC, Visa. Cozy and cluttered, Osaka’s subterranean setting feels like a quirky family restaurant in Japan, with its decor of retro lunchroom fixtures and paper screens. The sushi isn’t stellar, but lesser-known Japanese specialties are worth a try: hamachi-kama (yellowtail tuna neck), chawan mushi (saline egg custard spotted with green onions), agedashi tofu flavoured with ginger and soy, and comfy mains like rice-based domburis. (Sarah Musgrave, March 2007) Japanese Good bet $ $

properties.name: Osaka
properties.description: Posted by Asmaa2137 Bleury St., 514-849-3438. Lunch Tues.-Fri. 11:45 a.m. to 2 p.m.; supper Tues. to Thurs. 6 p.m. to 9:30 p.m.; Fri. 6 p.m. to 10:15 p.m.; Sat. 5:30 p.m. to 10:15 p.m.; Sun. to 9 p.m.; closed Mon. Licensed. MC, Visa. Cozy and cluttered, Osaka’s subterranean setting feels like a quirky family restaurant in Japan, with its decor of retro lunchroom fixtures and paper screens. The sushi isn’t stellar, but lesser-known Japanese specialties are worth a try: hamachi-kama (yellowtail tuna neck), chawan mushi (saline egg custard spotted with green onions), agedashi tofu flavoured with ginger and soy, and comfy mains like rice-based domburis. (Sarah Musgrave, March 2007) Japanese Good bet $ $

properties.name: Pullman
properties.description: Posted by Asmaa 3424 Parc Ave. (514) 288-7779 Open Tues. to Sat. 4:30 p.m. to 1 a.m. Licensed. All major cards. This stylish wine bar conjures up an old-fashioned appreciation for the finer things, from warm hand towels to vintage labels to fancy finger foods. Oysters Rockefeller or venison tartare are graciously served beneath a stemware chandelier that glints with the sounds of decidedly modern music. (Sarah Musgrave, Dec 2004 ) Wine bar 8313 Good bet

properties.name: Pullman
properties.description: Posted by Asmaa3424 Parc Ave montreal3424 Parc Ave. (514) 288-7779 Open Tues. to Sat. 4:30 p.m. to 1 a.m. Licensed. All major cards. properties.name: Restaurant Julien
properties.description: Posted by Asmaa 1191 Union Ave montreal1191 Union Ave. 514-871-1581. Lunch weekdays, dinner Mon to Sat. Major cards. Wheelchair access. If you\'re looking for a good square meal, an appealing setting and solicitous service, this is the restaurant for you. When ordering stick to classics like calf\'s liver with onions and duck salads. Desserts are a must, as is a bottle of wine, for the wine list here is interesting and well priced. In the summer, the gorgeous, posey-laden terrasse is a great spot for a power lunch or a romantic dinner. (Lesley Chesterman, April 2006) Bistro HH $ $ $

properties.name: Sur Bleury
properties.description: Posted by Asmaa1067 Bleury St. montreal1067 Bleury St. (514) 866-6161 Open Mon. & Tues. 11 a.m. to 3 p.m.; Wed. to Fri. 11 a.m. to 3 p.m. & 5 p.m. to 10 p.m.; closed weekends. Licensed. Visa, MC. It\'s not that this lofty sandwich and salad spot is doing anything so out of the ordinary, it\'s just that what it does do, it pulls off with a certain breezy optimism. Try trout gravlax and beet salad, pan-fried fish and pineapple sandwich with lime labneh or grilled cheese with aged Quebec cheddar and caramelized pear, and follow up with a mini pot au chocolat flavoured with Baileys for dessert. In the evening, a series of small plates includes an upscale version of poutine. (Sarah Musgrave, May 2005) Sandwiches 8297 Great Bet

properties.name: Sur Bleury
properties.description: Posted by Asmaa1067 Bleury St. (514) 866-6161 Open Mon. & Tues. 11 a.m. to 3 p.m.; Wed. to Fri. 11 a.m. to 3 p.m. & 5 p.m. to 10 p.m.; closed weekends. Licensed. Visa, MC. It\'s not that this lofty sandwich and salad spot is doing anything so out of the ordinary, it\'s just that what it does do, it pulls off with a certain breezy optimism. properties.name: Zen-Ya
properties.description: Posted by Asmaa486 Ste.Catherine St. W. (2nd floor) 514-904-1363. Lunch Mon.-Fri; dinner daily. Major cards. Located in an obscure walk-up in the heart of the city, this Japanese restaurant with a stunning contemporary decor offers a diverse and exotic menu. Sushi aficionados will not be disappointed. However, the wait staff is a bit too casual. Better at lunch, when reservations are recommended. (Lesley Chesterman, June 2006) Japanese HH 1ž2 $ $ $
